case_name: Commissioner of Income Tax Kerala v. West Coast Chemicals and Industries Ltd.

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 286 of 1961 filed by Commissioner of Income Tax Kerala

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 286 of 1961. Appeal from the judgment

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and order dated January 27, 1960 of Kerala High Court in T. R. Case No. 14 of 1955

anchor.surface_text: . Appeal from the judgment and order dated January 27, 1960, of the Kerala High Court in T. R. Case No. 14 of 1955.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on March 20, 1962 by HIDAYATULLAH, J.

anchor.surface_text: 1962. March 20. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by HIDAYATULLAH, J.- In this appeal

facts.text: Respondent West Coast Chemicals and Industries Ltd. referred to as assessee Company

anchor.surface_text: In this appeal by the Commissioner of Income Tax Kerala filed with certificate of the High Court of Kerala, an important question of law was raised before the High Court, which was answered against the Department. It arose in the following ,circumstances. The respondent, the West Coast Chemicals and Industries, Ltd.  referred to as the assessee Company

facts.text: Assessee Company incorporated in 1937 primarily to acquire and work match factory of A. V. Thomas at Medical

anchor.surface_text: was incorporated in 1937 primarily with the object of acquiring and working the- rights, title and interest in a match factory belonging to one A. V. Thomas at Medical.

facts.text: Memorandum of Association empowered Company to manufacture and deal in acids, alkalis and other chemicals

anchor.surface_text: The Memorandum of Association of the asseesee Company, however, empowered the Company to manufacture and deal in acids, alkalis and other chemicals.

facts.text: Assessee Company carried on business of manufacturing matches till account year ending April 30, 1941

anchor.surface_text: The assessee Company carried on its business of manufacturing matches till the account year ending, on April 30, 1941.

facts.text: Profits from business decreased due to war conditions, Company began manufacturing plywood chests for tea, paints and lemon grass oil

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter, the profits from the business became less and less due to War companyditions, and the assessee Company began to manufacture plywood chests for tea, paints and lemon grass oil.

facts.text: On May 9, 1943, assessee Company entered agreement with Rao Sahib Natesa Iyer for sale of lands, buildings, plant and machinery of match factory for Rs. 5,75,000 excluding manufactured goods, chemicals and raw materials

anchor.surface_text: On May, 9, 1943, the assessee Company entered into an agreement with one Rao Sahib Natesa Iyer for the sale of the lands, buildings, plant and machinery of its match factory for Rs. 5, 75,000. It was agreed that the price would number include manufactured goods, chemicals and other raw materials or any other asset number shown in the agreement of sale.

facts.text: Rs. 57,500 paid at time of first agreement, balance due in sixty days

anchor.surface_text: The purchaser was allowed sixty days for the payment of the balance of the price, Rs. 57,500 having been already paid at the time the agreement was entered into.

facts.text: Purchaser defaulted in payment, fresh agreement on August 9, 1943 for Rs. 7,35,000 including chemicals and paper for manufacture

anchor.surface_text: The purchaser made a default in payment, and on August 9, 1943, a fresh agreement was entered .into by the parties, this time for a companysideration of Rs. 7,35,000, and the sale included chemicals and paper for manufacture which had number been sold in the first instance.

facts.text: Directors stated in confidential report on August 1, 1944 to shareholders that price showed capital appreciation of six times cost price and sale of chemicals resulted in substantial profit

anchor.surface_text: In a companyfidential report made on August 1, 1944, to the shareholders, the Directors stated that the price obtained had shown a capital appreciation of about six times the companyt price, and the sale of chemicals had also resulted in a substantial profit.

facts.text: Assessment for account year ending April 30, 1944 completed by Deputy Commissioner on income of Rs. 36,498-6-4

anchor.surface_text: Meanwhile, the assessment of the Company for the, account year ending April 30, 1944, bad been companypleted by the Deputy Commissioner of Income-tax, and the assessee Company had been assessed on an income of Rs. 36,498-6-4.

facts.text: Deputy Commissioner issued notice under s. 25 of Travancore Income-tax Act to Company Liquidator alleging profits from sale of chemicals and paper escaped assessment

anchor.surface_text: The Deputy Commissioner of Income-tax then issued a numberice under s. 25 of the Travancore Income-tax Act to the Companys Liquidator on the ground that the profits from the sale of the chemicals and paper for manufacture had escaped assessment.

facts.text: Liquidator contended match manufacturing stopped, business wound up, only capital appreciation not business profit

anchor.surface_text: The Official Liquidator took up the position that the match manufacturing had been stopped, and that business had been wound up, and there thus only an appreciation of the capital assets and number a business profit, which, was liable to assessment.

facts.text: Deputy Commissioner held Company liable on profit of Rs. 2 lakhs from sale relying on Memorandum and Directors report

anchor.surface_text: The Deputy Commissioner, however, relying, upon the Memorandum of Association, which allowed the assessee Company to manufacture and sell chemicals, and on the Directors report, held that the assessee Company was liable to income-tax on a profit of Rs. 2 lakhs arising from this sale.

facts.text: Commissioner of Income-tax on appeal reduced assessable profits to Rs. 1,15,259

anchor.surface_text: The Commissioner of Income-tax on appeal, however, reduced the assessable profits to Rs. 1,15,259.

facts.text: Liquidator admitted profit from sale of chemicals was Rs. 1,15,259 before Commissioner

anchor.surface_text: Before the Commissioner, the Liquidator admitted that the profit from the sale of the chemicals wits Rs. 1, 15,259.

facts.text: Income-tax Appellate Tribunal held sale was trading sale not realisation after winding up as business not completely ceased

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal found that the business had number companypletely ceased to exist, since the assessee Company was carrying on manufacturing, on behalf of the purchaser, and, the sale companyld number be regarded as a realisation sale after the Company was wound up, but had the characteristics of a trading sale.

facts.text: Tribunal referred two questions to High Court at request of assessee Company

anchor.surface_text: At the request of the assessee Company, however, the Tribunal referred two questions to the High Court for its decision,

facts.text: Only two prior sales of chemicals by assessee: July 24, 1943 for Rs. 50 to educational institution and October 30, 1943 for Rs. 7-12-0 to stranger

anchor.surface_text: It maybe pointed out that prior to the sale of chemicals to the purchaser, the only evidence of sale of chemicals by the assessee Company was of two transactions. In the first transaction, there was a sale of chemicals on July 24, 1943,to an educational institution for Rs. 50 and another sale on October 30, 1943, to a stranger for Rs. 7-12-0.

facts.text: Kerala High Court held sale was realisation sale not liable to tax

anchor.surface_text: The High Court held that by the sale numberbusiness was done, and that the amount obtained was only by way of realisation sale and was number, therefore, liable to tax.

facts.text: Supreme Court held sale of chemicals and raw materials was winding up sale realising capital assets not trading profit

anchor.surface_text: In our judgment, this was a winding up sale with a view to realising the capital assets of the assessee Company and number a sale in the companyrse of business operations, which alone would had attracted tax, if profit resulted.
s. 25 of the Travancore Income-tax Act to the Companys Liquidator on the ground that the profits from the sale of the chemicals and paper for manufacture had escaped assessment.

concepts.unlisted_label: Section 25 of the Travancore Income-tax Act
concepts.unlisted_description: Provision for issuing notice where income has escaped assessment

anchor.surface_text: Mere realisation of assets is not trading but the completion of outstanding contracts after the dissolution of a firm, the commencement of liquidation of a company, or the winding up of the affairs of a trader, has been held to be trading The cases illustrating the question arising in such circumstances can be divided into two categories, first, those where the sales formed part of trading activities, and, second, those where the realisation was not an act of trading.

concepts.interpretation: Court endorses the distinction between sales as part of trading activities and mere realisations not amounting to trading as a sound principle for determining taxability of profits.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: toralist sold his property including all live-stock and plan

concepts.unlisted_label: Mere Realisation of Assets Not Trading
concepts.unlisted_description: Principle that realising assets on winding up or dissolution does not constitute trading unless part of ongoing trading activities

anchor.surface_text: The Privy Council held that this was wrong, pointing out that for profit to arise, there must be a trading, and that a mere alteration of a book-keeping entry was not evidence that there was profit.

concepts.interpretation: Applied to hold that without actual trading, mere book-keeping changes or slump sales do not generate taxable business profits.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: as a winding up sale. It observed that if the business be one of purely buying and selling, a profi

concepts.unlisted_description: Income-tax principle requiring actual trading activity for profits to be assessable as business income

anchor.surface_text: It observed that in Doughtys case the sale was a slump transaction, and was a winding up of the business rather than a trading.

concepts.interpretation: Where no separate identifiable price for stock-in-trade in a slump sale of entire business, cannot attribute trading profit to it.

concepts.unlisted_description: Sale of entire business/assets without separate valuation of components, treated as capital realisation not trading

anchor.surface_text: In our judgment, this was a winding up sale with a view to realising the capital assets of the assessee Company and not a sale in the course of business operations, which alone would had attracted tax, if profit resulted.

concepts.interpretation: Sale of chemicals and raw materials held to be winding up realisation of capital assets, not trading, despite MoA powers and directors' statements, given minimal prior sales and context of factory sale.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: rned. That the business of the Company was sold as a going companycern, and was, in fact, worked by the assessee Company on behalf of the buyer till t

concepts.unlisted_description: Test to classify sale during company winding up as capital receipt not liable to tax as business profit

anchor.surface_text: the essence of the matter however, is not that an extra amount has been gained by the selling out or the exchange but whether it can fairly be said that there was a trading from which alone profits can arise in business.

concepts.interpretation: Applied by examining facts like cessation of match business, minimal prior chemical sales, no sustained trading in chemicals, and sale as part of factory disposal.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: , formed the companysideration, was inferentially attributable to the stock. It was held, however, in that case that numbersum companyld be pitched up

concepts.unlisted_description: Multi-factor inquiry into whether transaction occurs in course of carrying on business or merely realises assets

issues.text: whether the transaction of sale of the raw materials along with the business,including machinery, plant and premises is a revenue sale, and whether in the facts and circumstances of the case, the sum of Rs. 1,15,254 has been rightly charged to income-tax

anchor.surface_text: 1  whether the transaction of sale of the raw materials along with the business,including machinery, plant and premises is a revenue sale, and whether in the facts and circumstances of the case, the sum of Rs. 1,15,254has been rightly charged to income-tax

issues.text: whether the decision that the sale of match, machinery and premises, was distinct from the sale of chemicals is legally warranted and whether there was legally a single, transaction of the entire match factory inclusive of raw materials

anchor.surface_text: 2  whether the decision that the sale of match, machinery and premises, was distinct from the sale of chemicals is legally war- ranted and whether there was legally a single, transaction of the entire match factory inclusive of raw materials?

issues.text: whether there can be said to be a sale in the carrying on of the business in respect of the chemicals and other raw materials

anchor.surface_text: The question, therefore, is whether there can be said to be a sale in the carrying on of the business in respect of the chemicals and other raw materials.

issues.text: whether the business was being wound up and the sale, a realisation sale, or whether trading was going on in spite of the winding up, so as to attract tax on profits made

anchor.surface_text: Such a question, fortunately, does number arise in the-present case, which can be decided on the narrow ground whether the business was being wound up and the sale, a realisation sale, or whether trading was going on in spite of the winding up, so as to attract tax on profits made.

anchor.surface_text: The Official Liquidator took up the position that the match manufacturing had been stopped, and that business had been wound up, and there thus only an appreciation of the capital assets and not a business profit, which, was liable to assessment.

arguments.claim: stock-in-trade only subject of trade, raw materials sold in realisation sale after winding up not ordinary trading

anchor.surface_text: An appeal was then filed before the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal at Trivandrum, and the assessee Company contended that a stock-in-trade could only be that which was the subject of trade, and that the stock of raw material was not sold in the course of ordinary trading but in a realisation sale after the Company had been wound up.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: winding up sale, number with a view to trading in chemicals and raw material but to close down the business and to realise the assets. There was, in f

arguments.claim: business not completely ceased, carrying on manufacturing on behalf of purchaser, sale was trading sale not realisation after winding up

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal found that the business had not completely ceased to exist, since the assessee Company was carrying on manufacturing, on behalf of the purchaser, and, the sale could not be regarded as a realisation sale after the Company was wound up, but had the characteristics of a trading sale.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: rned. That the business of the Company was sold as a going companycern, and was, in fact, worked by the assessee Company on behalf of the buyer till t

arguments.court_reasoning: manufacturing on behalf of buyer, agreement indicated keeping factory going for buyer not own trading

arguments.claim: by the sale no business was done, amount obtained only by way of realisation sale not liable to tax

anchor.surface_text: The High Court held that by the sale no business was done, and that the amount obtained was only by way of realisation sale and was not, therefore, liable to tax.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: winding up sale, number with a view to trading in chemicals and raw material but to close down the business and to realise the assets. There was, in f

arguments.claim: Memorandum allows manufacturing and selling chemicals, past sales of chemicals, first excluded chemicals for lower price then included for larger price, identifiable profit of Rs. 1,15,259, thus trading profit taxable

anchor.surface_text: rho argument of the Department also raised before the High Court proceeds in this way. The Department refers to the Memorandum of Association under which the assessee Company was to carry on the business of manufacturing and selling chemicals, that in the past it bad sold chemicals, that in the first sale of its assets it had excluded chemicals and some other raw materials necessary for the manufacture of matches and had sold the concern for a lesser price, that later it included chemicals and raw materials and obtained a larger price, and that admittedly there was an identifiable profit of Rs. 1,15,259 on the sale of the chemicals and raw materials. The Department, therefore contends that the amount of Rs. 1, 15,259 was properly brought to tax as a trading profit.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ing companypany, was treated as its value for transfer purpose, and the balance of a slump price, which, with an under taking to discharge liabilities

arguments.court_reasoning: MoA not used for chemicals trading, only petty prior sales, price difference does not prove trading, winding up context

arguments.claim: distinction between sales part of trading activities and mere realisations not trading is sound

anchor.surface_text: Mere realisation of assets is not trading but the completion of outstanding contracts after the dissolution of a firm, the commencement of liquidation of a company, or the winding up of the affairs of a trader, has been held to be trading The cases illustrating the question arising in such circumstances can be divided into two categories, first, those where the sales formed part of trading activities, and, second, those where the realisation was not an act of trading. This distinction, in our opinion, is a sound one.

arguments.claim: Californian Copper Syndicate v. Harris supports taxing as trading profit since within company objects

anchor.surface_text: In the well-known case of Californian Copper Syndicate v. Harris , the difference between the purchase price and the value of the shares for which the property was exchanged was considered as profit assessable to income-tax. There, the company was formed for the purpose of acquiring and reselling mining properties, and though what it had acquired had all been sold or exchanged, the transaction was considered a business transaction failing within the avowed objects, of the Company.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: eir Lordships to appreciate. The Privy Council made a distinction between a sale of the entire stock as a part of trading and a sale of the same stock

arguments.court_reasoning: distinguished on narrow facts, unlike winding up sale here

arguments.claim: Tebrau Johore Rubber Syndicate Ltd. v. Farmer supports capital appreciation not assessable profit

anchor.surface_text: The case has been accepted as decided on these narrow facts, in Tebrau Johore Rubber Syndicate Ltd. v. Farmer , in which a different conclusion was reached on slightly different facts. There also, the Company was formed with the object of acquiring rubber estates and for developing them. Under the Memorandum, the Company had the power to sell its properties. Two properties having been acquired and the funds having run out, they were sold but at a profit. This profit was considered as an appreciation of capital and not as assessable profit.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: to retire. It may well be accepted that they did so intend yet the intention of a man cannot be companysidered as determining what it is that his acts

arguments.claim: Doughty v. Commissioner of Taxes: no profit without trading, slump sale no separate stock valuation taxable

anchor.surface_text: The Privy Council held that this was wrong, pointing out that for profit to arise, there must be a trading, and that a mere alteration of a book-keeping entry was not evidence that there was profit. It also held that the sale was of the entire assets, and that the price represented a payment for the entire business without a separate sale or valuation of this stock-in-trade for purposes of sale.

arguments.claim: sale was winding up sale realising capital assets not sale in course of business operations taxable only if trading

anchor.surface_text: In our judgment, this was a winding up sale with a view to realising the capital assets of the assessee Company and not a sale in the course of business operations, which alone would had attracted tax, if profit resulted.

arguments.claim: Memorandum power to sell chemicals irrelevant as clause never used, only two petty prior sales no evidence of continued trading

anchor.surface_text: The fact that the clause in the Memorandum gave power to the Company to sell chemicals cannot be used in this connection, because the evidence clearly shows that that clause was never used and the two sales of chemicals through the years were too petty in themselves to afford evidence of a continued or sustained trading In chemicals.

arguments.claim: carrying on manufacturing on behalf of buyer per agreement not own trading

anchor.surface_text: That the business of the Company was sold as a going concern, and was, in fact, worked by the assessee Company on behalf of the buyer till the entire consideration was paid, makes no difference, because the agreement clearly indicated that the, assessee Company was keeping the factory going, not on its own behalf but entirely on behalf of the buyer.

arguments.claim: no identifiable price for chemicals except by comparing two agreements, insufficient to infer trading

anchor.surface_text: There was, in fact, no identifiable price for the chemicals and raw materials except by comparing the two prices offered to be paid by the buyer, that is to say, the price without the chemicals and raw materials and the price with them. From that alone, however, it is impossible to infer that the chemicals and raw materials were sold in the ordinary way of business or that the assessee Company was carrying on a trading busi- ness.

arguments.claim: essence is whether there was trading from which profits arise

anchor.surface_text: the essence of the matter however, is not that an extra amount has been gained by the selling out or the exchange but whether it can fairly be said that there was a trading from which alone profits can arise in business.

holdings.text: In our judgment, this was a winding up sale with a view to realising the capital assets of the assessee Company and not a sale in the course of business operations, which alone would had attracted tax, if profit resulted.

anchor.surface_text: In our judgment, this was a winding up sale with a view to realising the capital assets of the assessee Company and not a sale in the course of business operations, which alone would had attracted tax, if profit resulted.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applied multi-factor trading test to facts including cessation of match business, minimal prior chemical sales, no sustained trading, MoA unused, part of factory disposal in winding up.

holdings.text: The fact that the clause in the Memorandum gave power to the Company to sell chemicals cannot be used in this connection, because the evidence clearly shows that that clause was never used and the two sales of chemicals through the years were too petty in themselves to afford evidence of a continued or sustained trading In chemicals.

anchor.surface_text: The fact that the clause in the Memorandum gave power to the Company to sell chemicals cannot be used in this connection, because the evidence clearly shows that that clause was never used and the two sales of chemicals through the years were too petty in themselves to afford evidence of a continued or sustained trading In chemicals.

holdings.reasoning_summary: MoA clause authorizing chemical dealings irrelevant absent evidence of actual use or sustained trading; only two petty prior sales insufficient.

holdings.text: That the business of the Company was sold as a going concern, and was, in fact, worked by the assessee Company on behalf of the buyer till the entire consideration was paid, makes no difference, because the agreement clearly indicated that the assessee Company was keeping the factory going, not on its own behalf but entirely on behalf of the buyer.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Post-agreement factory operation was for buyer's benefit per agreement terms, not indicia of assessee's own trading activity.

holdings.text: There was, in fact, no identifiable price for the chemicals and raw materials except by comparing the two prices offered to be paid by the buyer, that is to say, the price without the chemicals and raw materials and the price with them. From that alone, however, it is impossible to infer that the chemicals and raw materials were sold in the ordinary way of business or that the assessee Company was carrying on a trading business.

From that alone, however, it is impossible to infer that the chemicals and raw materials were sold in the ordinary way of business or that the assessee Company was carrying on a trading busi- ness.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Difference between first and second agreement prices does not establish separate trading sale of chemicals; no distinct valuation.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Core test for taxable business profit requires actual trading activity, not mere capital gain; drawn from precedents.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Endorses doctrinal distinction between sales as trading vs mere asset realisations during winding up, as per Halsbury and cases.

holdings.text: There is no doubt, in this case, that the assessee Company was wound up at least in so far as its match manufacture was concerned.

anchor.surface_text: Californian Copper Syndicate v. Harris  1 , the difference between the purchase price and the value of the shares for which the property was exchanged was companysidered as profit assessable to income-tax. There, the companypany was formed for the purpose of acquiring and reselling mining properties, and though what it had acquired had all been Bold or exchanged, the transaction was companysidered a business transaction failing within the avowed objects, of the Company.

precedents.cited_proposition: difference between purchase price and value of shares for which property exchanged is profit assessable to income-tax when company formed to acquire and resell mining properties
precedents.cited_holding: transaction was business transaction within objects of company

precedents.citation: Tebrau  Johore  Rubber Syndicate Ltd. v. Farmer  2

anchor.surface_text: Tebrau  Johore  Rubber Syndicate Ltd. v. Farmer  2 , in which a different companyclusion was reached on slightly different facts. There also, the Company was formed with the object of acquiring rubber estates and for developing them. Under the Memo- randum, the Company had the power to sell its properties. Two properties having been acquired and the funds having run out, they were sold but at a profit.

precedents.case_name: Tebrau Johore Rubber Syndicate Ltd v Farmer
precedents.cited_proposition: profit from sale of acquired rubber estates after development is capital appreciation not assessable profit

precedents.cited_proposition: mere change in book-keeping entry not profit; sale of entire assets in slump transaction is not trading profit
precedents.cited_holding: no separate sale or valuation of stock-in-trade for sale purposes

precedents.citation: Commissioner of Taxation  W. A.  v. Newman  II

anchor.surface_text: Commissioner of Taxation  W. A.  v. Newman  II. A person who carried on business in Western Australia as a pastoralist sold his property including all live-stock and plant, as a going companycern. The Commissioner of Taxation for the State apportioned the purchase money in respect of the live-stock, and assessed the amount which was received in excess, as income derived from carrying on a business.

precedents.case_name: Commissioner of Taxation WA v Newman
precedents.cited_proposition: sale of entire property including livestock as going concern to end business is capital not trading profit
precedents.cited_holding: transaction not during or for purpose of carrying on business but to put end to it

anchor.surface_text: Anson v. Commissioner of Taxes  2 . In that case also, a sheep farmer sold his entire stock of sheep. He had the practice of placing on his sheep at the beginning and end of each year an arbitrary value without reference to the, actual market value. When he sold his entire stock, a numberinal profit of pound 5,000 odd appeared, and he was assessed on it.

precedents.cited_proposition: sale of entire stock-in-trade of sheep farmer results in assessable trading profit
precedents.cited_holding: sheep are stock-in-trade, appreciation assessable regardless of sold at once or over time

anchor.surface_text: Doughtys case  3  did number say much, but enough to cast a doubt upon it. This is what the Privy Council said at p. 335. precedents.cited_holding: sale in slump transaction is winding up not trading

precedents.citation: J. R. OKane Co. v. The Commissioners of Inland Revenue  2

anchor.surface_text: J. R. OKane Co. v. The Commissioners of Inland Revenue  2 , the appellants carried on business as wine and spirit merchants. They then wished to retire from the business and sent a circular letter to their customers. During the year, they sold their bole stock to diverse customers.-, and the question was whether they were still carrying on their trade during that period,

precedents.case_name: J R OKane Co v Commissioners of Inland Revenue
precedents.cited_proposition: sales of stock while intending to retire can still be trading if in ordinary course
precedents.cited_holding: trading was being carried on based on Commissioners' finding

precedents.citation: The Commissioner of Inland Revenue v. Old Bashmills Distillery Co., Ltd.  in Liquidation   1

anchor.surface_text: The Commissioner of Inland Revenue v. Old Bashmills Distillery Co., Ltd.  in Liquidation   1  was one decided on a finding, in support of which there was evidence. The two cases relied upon by the Department and the assessee Company respectively do number shed any light upon the problem before us because the central decision in both of them was whether the Commissioners finding was justified or number.

precedents.cited_proposition: profits taxable if Commissioners find trading continuing during liquidation
